Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2008 04:26AM miss-di wrote: Dear Barbara, I am so sorry you got that news and in the manner you did. I am a nurse and have to step around Doctors all the time.  They range anywhere from the niciest caring people, to the meanest and rudest.  (this goes for nurses, techs, secretaries etc.) I feel, especially with breast cancer, you should at least be able to like any and all people dealing with you.  Our self esteem takes such a punch and then having to put up with rude and nasty people who are supposed to be taking care of you is another insult.  We should never feel we have to bow down to any person taking care of us.  I quit my onc for just that reason.  I found a new one who makes me feel very comfortable, even when giving bad news. The days of treating Drs as if they are Gods is gone.  The new, younger doctors actually deal with this better than those who have been in the field a very long time.  There is also a Hiearchy in the phys. world.  General/Family, Internal Med, General Surgeons, Ortho surg, Heart surg,Neuro surg, brain surg.  They tend to have much bigger attitudes about themselves in that order.  This is not to say they all have crappy bedside manner, but alot do. Surgeons are notoriously cold. I agree with those who said keep your appointments, you will just have to set them up again.  I differ with the opinion to stay with any Dr. you can not handle.  You have time, check around with others who have had surgery, see who they reccomend.  You have the right to feel as good as you can about everything you will be choosing from now on. My best to you and everyone else, Di
Posts.Title: Not sure where to go now BarbaraS HeatherBLocklear

Posts.Title: Intruder on our Boards ruths2 chemosabi

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2008 11:55PM miss-di wrote: I believe jaw pain, teeth grinding is definitely a side effect of some of the meds we take.  Never had it before, have it now bad, so much so it wakes me in the middle of the night several times and I have to take Advil during the day.  I even find myself clenching during the day now.   My newest meds are Xeloda and Tykerb. My belief is the docotors don't know everything.  If enough people do not say the same thing to their doctors, how are they going to know?  We all say the same big things, diarrhea, constipation, hair loss, but never the smaller things.  Fortunately I have an oncologist who believes me, such as when I had one treatment of Navelbine.  The neck, jaw, face pain was so bad I almost went to ER.  The on call doctor never heard of it, nor did my Onc, but she researched it and yes, it is a rare side effect. My belief in this whole mess is, if something is way out of the ordinary for you, and you just started a new med, it probably has something to do with the med.  It doesn't matter if it is one of the usual side effects, everyone is different.  I for one am happy to see someone else ask about the jaw clenching.  I bought a $35.00 night gaurd at pharmacy yesterday.  I slept somewhat better and did not have to take Advil this morning. My best to all and Happy New Year, Di PS: I read this site and use it for reference for my visits.  I will tell my Onc, "well maybe you have not heard of this because you have a smaller group to hear from, but please, go to www.breastcancer.org and see what many women are saying."  There are way to many of us saying the same thing one this site, to many many doctors who might be hearing it for the first time.  If your doctor is good enough to look here, they may not poo poo you as much.

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 06:02AM miss-di wrote: Dear same, Are you on an HMO?  If so, call your PCP and get your appt. moved up and be strong.  What is your family history for breast cancer?  VERY IMPORTANT no matter what age you are. Bleeding from nipple is not normal, be aggressive, take care of yourself and do not give up because anyone says no.  Call insurance company directly and get an appt. as soon as possible. As a nurse, I know they can ALWAYS work you in, anywhere. Good luck, Di

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 01:16PM miss-di wrote: I had several, clumped together, clavicle lymph nodes taken out.  This did nothing for the rest of my nodes, and if it did nothing else it made me feel better. I was told, if there was only nodes in one area, I could have them radiated.  I so hope this would be the case because I would have jumped on the radiation, but it was not. Either way, I would do it again the same way.  Of course, I will be having other treatments forever, but somehow, I feel better they took those out. Good luck in your decison. My best to all, Diane

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2007 01:18PM miss-di wrote: My surgeon found lump clavicle area during another procedure.  It was scalene node.  I went from NED for 5yrs. to StageIV in one day.  Cancer is in chest, abdomen and liver. Herceptin every 3 weeks and Arimidex daily. My biopsy was done two days after finding lump.  I also do not believe in waiting.  I truly hope yours all negative.  Best to all. Diane
Posts.Title: Breast cancer spread to lymph node in neck sockmonkey yangtan

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 02:44AM miss-di wrote: I agree with those who say 3 months is to long to wait.  Although it is true, women your age are less suseptible to breast cancer, it is not impossible by any means.  If physician felt the lump it would not be unreasonableto at least have an ultrasound and then if needed a mammogram, sooner than three months. Breast cysts though tend to be painful during your cycle and moveable,  Normally, but I believe there is nothing normal about breast cancer, the cancer lumps are said to be nonpainful and nonmoveable. But I tend to always caution on the side of it might be so let's check it further. Good luck, Di

Hope all turned out well for you, and my best to all. Di

Posts.Title: I hate pink ribbons, but.......... Watson Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 09:17AM miss-di wrote: Dear Lilac and all, This week I am in the same boat as you. QOL sucks right now.  I have been on something for almost 2 years straight, some worse than others.  Herceptin 17 mos, arimidex 7mos, Xeloda 3mos, Tykerb, Aromisin, Abraxane, more Herceptin,  now suggesting A/C, Avastin, Gem/Carbo or Xeloda/Ixempra.  I'm just ready to cry. The leg pain from the Abraxane is really getting to me scale of 1-10, sometimes it's a 12.  Dealling with dropping things and hitting things with my hands because I can't feel them, but really tired of that also. I'm so tired of everyone wanting me to be OK and pretending I'm soing better just so they don't hurt.  I'm tired of having no real life of my own, I've forgotten what I used to be like. I so want to go back to work, but they won't let me do that either.  It's all about the cancer, can't get away from it.  Do I want to take this pill for pain or not, do I want to be able to go to the bathroom within the next 4 days, can't make real plans for a week or two from now because I don't know how I'll feel, always the same answer, "yes, I want to do that, but I won't know till that day." Yep, I'm down. Yep, I'm so tired and in pain.  Yep I just want to cry, but can't because I have to be strong for everybody else, and that doesn't even include the other crap in my life. I'm tired of trying to act as if I can live a half way normal life as they keep telling me I can when nothing is normal.   I'm going to ask about a break also, may just a few months of summer. My best to all, Di
Posts.Title: Thinking about quiting chemo Lilac Godsgal

Posts.Content: miss-di wrote: Hi ladies, I was wondering if anyone else out there has opted for Cyberknife?  Went in for liver ablation, but it was to big.  Was told my only other choice was having half my liver out and I am not ready for that yet.  Had researched Cyberknife and decided to go with that as if it didn't work I could still have liver surgery, but I couldn't do it the other way around. My Cyberknife was on November 6th and my repeat CT is scheduled for next week. My best to everyone and I hope we all have a better 2009 than our 2008. Di  May an angel walk beside you. Dx 7/28/2007, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 3/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Cyberknife miss-di miss-di

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 04:59PM - edited Jan 6, 2009 05:03PM by miss-di I had the cyberknife to my liver, sternum had reg rads. Just got my CT results from yesterday, the large tumor I had in my liver has shrunk or died almost completely.  This is good.  It is a painless procedure and my Oncologist is very happy with results.   Good luck to you, I hope it does the trick!

I talked to my Onc last week, and she is writing an RX for the ring, even though I am "mildly" er+. She said it has been ok'd for breast cancer pt's at this time. I debated, but it has gotten to the point the drying is causing pain and chaffing all the time. It makes me angry that , that what makes us women, can kill us, is taken away, and makes you miserable. Looking for some relief! My best to all, Di

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2008 04:59AM miss-di wrote: I worked, as a nurse, while going through chemo/rads.  I changed to the private duty side until I was over treatments. I had a few days that I could not make it, but company and family knew what was going on and everything worked out. My chemos were on Thur so I would have time in between and my rads were in afternoon so I went directly after work and then home to rest. Everyone is different.  This was 6 years ago and I keep hearing chemo is a little easier now.  Good luck to you and everyone else, Diane
